Nice try, Kevin Dowd. I regret that you are yet another conservative who just can't quit the urban myth that Obama is a socialist. Redistribute the wealth? The only wealth he redistributed was from the taxpayers to the coffers of Wall Street. The only care in health care was the solicitude toward the insurance companies and the pharmaceutical lobby. The only "Nanny State" in operation is the one that protects the oligarchs. And you might have noticed that the only Democrats who lost were of the Blue Dog, Republican-lite variety. Ninety-five percent of the "progressives" were returned - you know, the ones who actually fought for the public option.

The Tea Party anger is real. My hope is that they bring their anger into the halls of Congress and wreak havoc with the establishment Republican way of doing things instead of collapsing like wet noodles. I am really looking forward to the steamy chemistry between Rand Paul and Mitch McConnell. From what little I have seen of Rand, he will not take being called "Junior" lightly. I can hear the sound of stomping feet already.

Don't worry about the Democrats, Kevin. They may have lost the skirmish, but the real battle is ahead with the Lady in Red, Ms. Sarah Palin. Not only is she tweeting about quantitative easing, she gave a rousing speech Wednesday night defending the right of parents to stuff sugar into their children's mouths. She is the Republican Party's worst nightmare, and all I can say is a big thank you to John McCain.

Obama may be beyond salvation, but right now he's the lesser of two evils. He showed off his moves in "So You Think You Can Dance", Asian style. When he comes home, his next appearance will be on "So You Think You Can Govern." Maybe the second half of Term One will be his comeback. Never say never. After all, having just seen Nightmare Bush again, even a sellout is better than a psychopath.

It makes me think that maybe the rise in bullying and the general lack of empathy in american culture is related to the way the generations are separated. Now it's absolutely possible to have virtually no, or very limited, interactions with babies until you yourself are a parent. And it's just as easy to have almost no interactions with babies once your own children are out of that stage (until they grow up and have their own kids.) In the past we were much more intergenerational. Maybe that's better.

Ms. Dowd, your brother clearly has been watching too much Fox News, rather than consuming more reality-based news.

As for the point about Speaker Pelosi, the last thing Democrats should be doing is basing their decision about who should be the House Democratic leader on the thoughts of Republicans. The simple fact is that no matter what Democrats do, Republicans will attack them. So, rather than looking weak by cowering in fear of expected attacks, Democrats should do what is right for their country and party, and then proudly stand behind their actions. Choosing Speaker Pelosi to remain as Democratic House leader is a first step in rejecting the Republican noise machine and being bold.

The reality is that Pelosi did a great job in 2005-2006 helping the Democrats regain the House majority in 2006, then helped expand that majority in 2008, and then had the most successful progressive legislative record in 2009-2010 of any Congress since the Great Society Congress of the mid-1960s. She has been an effective progressive leader who deserves to stay on as the Democratic leader in the House.

It sounds like a fantastic program.

I wouldn't look for a neurobiological explanation, but would rather stick with this one: The baby is an audience that demands an empathic response. The kids momentarily put down their entrenched classroom social roles and take up the role of "interacting with a baby." A puppy (or hamster) might serve the same purpose; and relatedly, I remember our high school principal commenting on how well-behaved we all were when we came in, dressed up in the evening with our parents, for some kind of ceremony. It's all about triggering a particular social role--in this case, a good-citizen or caring-human one.

Reading this reminded me of the programs where prisoners raise seeing eye dog puppies. And the results are very similar, so perhaps there is a connection there. When humans are given the opportunity to care for something that needs them, it can change the way they see themselves, and how they behave toward other people.

This is a great idea, and it definitely pushes all our evolutionary buttons.  Another idea that I think would work similarly would be to bring in a puppy.  Dogs evolved along with us, and we have an instinctual love for them as well!

Oh, I thought Kevin would be back to gloat. Unfortunately, like so many of his Republican friends, he is living in Fantasyland. Let's hit his high points.

"The voters left no doubt about their feeling for his super-nanny state where the government controls all aspects of their lives and freedoms." First, Americans of all political persuasions do want what Kevin calls a "super-nanny state." They want their Social Security, their Medicare, their unemployment checks, their food stamps, their veterans' benefits, their farm subsidies (think Chuck Grassley here), their tax deductions, and, yes, even those porky earmarks. True enough, the selfish ones -- usually called Republicans -- don't necessarily want other people to have them.

As for controlling their lives & taking away their freedoms, that's the Republican platform. It's Republicans who want government to decide how men and women should conduct their intimate relationships; it's Republicans who want to tell men and women whom they can love and whom they can marry; it's Republicans who want to tell women how to manage unwanted pregnancies; it's Republicans who want to tell people who can and mostly who can't organize or join a union; it's Republicans who want to tell litigants how much money they can win in court. Republicans want to get in bed with you & go to work with you. And if somebody does you wrong, you won't even have the freedom to tell it to the judge. Can't get much more controlling than that.

"The president is ... a true believer in a redistribution of wealth controlled by big government." Every voter and every politician wants to redistribute the wealth. That's what government does. Now, Republicans want to redistribute the wealth to the wealthy, and they've been disturbingly successful at doing so. (Truth be told, ConservaDems have helped them.) We now have the greatest income disparity between rich & everybody else that we've had since the Gilded Age. Republicans have taken from the middle class & given to the rich. Republicans have passed law upon law aimed at increasing that income gap -- from straightforward laws like tax cuts and union suppression, to more convoluted ones, like encouraging outsourcing, allowing banks to charge usurious rates and treating corporations like people or amorphous gods, depending upon which is most beneficial to corporate interests. I hope you're rich, Kevin, because if you are, your Republican friends are going to make you richer. If you aren't, they're going to redistribute a good chuck of your teeny slice of the pie to somebody who is rich.

"On Nov. 2, voters across every spectrum loudly stated their preference for a return to American exceptionalism, self-reliance, limited government and personal freedoms." First, many of the votes were protest votes: voters don't like either party, and in fact, they like & trust Republicans less than they do Democrats. They voted for "Not Incumbent." That's not voting FOR "American exceptionalism, self-reliance, limited government and personal freedoms." That's voting AGAINST the team that didn't improve the economy enough. One reason Democrats didn't improve the economy enough, of course, was that obstructionist Republicans limited what Democrats could do.

But more important, millions of eligible voters didn't vote at all. Forty-five million fewer voters turned out to the polls in 2010 than voted in 2008. That turns out to be close to a third of the 2010 electorate who just stayed home. Sitting out the election is, of course, another form of protest. Rick Hertzberg noted earlier this week that "the members of this year’s truncated electorate were also whiter, markedly older, and more habitually Republican: if the franchise had been limited to them two years ago..., John McCain would be President today." Old, white Republicans are not exactly "every spectrum."

In short, Kevin, every one of your premises is wrong. But don't feel bad, Kevin. Republicans usually get things wrong. You've got company. Just not as much company as you think you have.

India and China are both large, poor developing countries with very low wages. Yet India is a far better trading partner for the US than China.

India sells $1.55 worth to us for every $1 that the US sells to India.
China sells $4.11 worth to us for every $1 that the US sells to China.

Some developing countries are even better customers than India. For example Brazil.

Brazil sells $0.69 worth to us for every $1 that the US sells to Brazil.

Former Communist states like China and Russia seem to be very very bad trading partners for America.

Russia sells $4.69 worth to us for every $1 that the US sells to Russia.

The problem with trade arises because of the way that countries like China and Russia game the system for their benefit. The refusal of the US government to take action against these mercantilists is an enormous act of betrayal.

In addition to all of the problematic results of Republicans winning back a number of governships and statehouses that this editorial mentions, another frightening impact is that the Republican takeover will further hinder efforts to help our economy recover nationally.

Keep in mind that a big reason that President Obama's stimulus legislation was able to only stabilize our economy, rather than achieve a full recovery, is that the stimulative impact of the federal spending was fully offset by spending cuts and layoffs at the state and local governmental levels (in part because Republicans and Blue Dogs prevented the stimulus from including sufficient aid to state and local governments). Now, new Republican governors and legislators are promising even further state and local government spending cuts. It is almost as if they want the economy to continue to suffer.
